answers.answer: No point in stopping the tamsulosin as this does not take away the effects on the IRIS.  Doctors have tried it for even a month and it still has done something to make the surgery more difficult which is termed "floppy iris."  This seems to be a permanent effect even if you stop the medicine.  Try and find him a cataract surgeon who is well known and possibly has trained in the US, UK, or Europe.  There are some great surgeons out of Pakistan, I just don't know of any specifically to recommend.  Most cases with Tamsulosin still go just fine and as long as the doctor knows to be careful and prepared, it should not be a problem.HV

question: Hi,I am from Pakistan and I am writing to you because this issue is stressing me out alot. My father has been recommended the cateract surgery by his eye doctor. He is 65years old, recently diagonosed with parkinsons for which he is taking azilect (0.5mg) and he also has diabetes and a mild prostrate condition for which he is taking tamsulosin (0.4mg).I told his doctor about tamsulosin, but i believe he has not taken it very seriously. In addition considering the medical care in my country, i dont think he will be taking any extra measures for my father. After reading the information online i am very worried and i would like to know if he should leave tamsulosin 2weeks prior to the surgery? But then what about after the surgery, how long should he stop taking it? Can you help me out here. Thankyou so much for your time.Faiza
title: Cateract surgery and Tamsulosin
